title: Barbara Marcus on Being Ready for New Opportunities
text:
When Barbara Marcus went to work in the world of children’s books, many colleagues questioned her decision.

At the time, children’s publishing was viewed as less prestigious than publishing books for adults. In the industry, some surmised her career would hit a dead end.

Then, the Harry Potter novels changed all that. Ms. Marcus was head of children’s book publishing at Scholastic when the publishing house acquired the American rights to “Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone,” which propelled her and its author, J.K. Rowling, into publishing fame. The book, published in 1997, is one of the best selling books of all time.

Her advice to women who want to take career risks that others deem inadvisable: Know your value and be on the lookout for new projects.

“If you always keep your head down you may miss great opportunities,” Ms. Marcus says in this Secrets of Wealthy Women podcast with Veronica Dagher.

Ms. Marcus is now the president and publisher of the children’s division at Random House and the president of the Education Fund of the Women’s Forum of New York. She explains the importance of mentoring other women and living below your means.

description: Barbara Marcus is a publishing veteran and the president of the children's division at Random House. She tells The Wall Street Journal's Veronica Dagher how a powerful career in business and marketing prepared her for her latest chapter of success.
